elements.content: A new luminescent Zn­(II)-based metal–organic framework (MOF), [Zn2(TPOM)­(NDC)2]·3.5H2O (Zn-MOF; TPOM = tetrakis­(4-pyridyloxymethylene)­methane and H2ndc = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid), was successfully synthesized by a hydrothermal reaction. The MOF exhibits excellent luminescence emission, and it can detect Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions with high selectivity, well antiinterference performance, and short response time. In addition, Zn-MOF was selected as a parent coordination compound to encapsulate Eu3+ cations to obtain a Eu3+-incorporated sample (Eu3+@Zn-MOF). Subsequently, we explored the potential application of Eu3+@Zn-MOF as a probe for the selective sensing of Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions, and it revealed that we could differentiate Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions by the combination Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. More importantly, it represents the first example of MOF-based luminescent sensors which can detect and differentiate Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions selectively. And the possible sensing mechanism was discussed in detail.
elements.clean_text: A new luminescent Zn(II)-based metal-organic framework (MOF), [Zn2(TPOM)(NDC)2]⋅3.5H2O (Zn-MOF; TPOM = tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene)methane and H2ndc = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid), was successfully synthesized by a hydrothermal reaction. The MOF exhibits excellent luminescence emission, and it can detect Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions with high selectivity, well antiinterference performance, and short response time. In addition, Zn-MOF was selected as a parent coordination compound to encapsulate Eu3+ cations to obtain a Eu3+-incorporated sample (Eu3+@Zn-MOF). Subsequently, we explored the potential application of Eu3+@Zn-MOF as a probe for the selective sensing of Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions, and it revealed that we could differentiate Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions by the combination Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. More importantly, it represents the first example of MOF-based luminescent sensors which can detect and differentiate Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions selectively. And the possible sensing mechanism was discussed in detail.

elements.content: A 3D Zn-MOF was successfully constructed which can detect Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions sensitively and selectively. More importantly, the Eu3+@Zn-MOF was got, and we can differentiate Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions by the combination of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. It represents the first example of MOF-based luminescent probes for differentiating Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions through fluorescence measurement.
elements.clean_text: A 3D Zn-MOF was successfully constructed which can detect Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions sensitively and selectively. More importantly, the Eu3+@Zn-MOF was got, and we can differentiate Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions by the combination of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. It represents the first example of MOF-based luminescent probes for differentiating Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions through fluorescence measurement.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have gathered significant attention because of their potential practical applications, which include gas storage, separation, drug delivery, catalysis, and sensing. Among them, luminescence sensing has attracted more and more attention because of its high sensibility, selectivity, well antiinterference performance, quick response, operability, and recyclability. Among the various functional luminescent MOFs, Ln­(III)-functionalized MOFs, which can be obtained by postsynthetic modification of MOFs, are becoming more and more fascinating because, compared with the original MOFs, the Ln­(III)-functionalized MOFs could have different excitation spectra. If the excitation spectrum of the MOF (donor) shows a certain degree of overlap with the UV–vis absorption spectrum of the analyte (acceptor), there is likely to be a competitive energy absorption process between them. The detection results may be different by different excitation wavelengths, so we can combine the Ln­(III)-functionalized MOF and the original MOF to distinguish the analytes effectively. For these reasons, efforts have been made to fabricate Ln­(III)-functionalized luminescence-sensing MOFs. Over the past few decades, a few Ln­(III)-functionalized luminescent MOFs for sensing cations and anions have been realized. However, no reports about combining the fluorescent detection properties of the Ln­(III)-functionalized MOF and the original MOF have been found.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have gathered significant attention because of their potential practical applications, which include gas storage, separation, drug delivery, catalysis, and sensing. Among them, luminescence sensing has attracted more and more attention because of its high sensibility, selectivity, well antiinterference performance, quick response, operability, and recyclability. Among the various functional luminescent MOFs, Ln(III)-functionalized MOFs, which can be obtained by postsynthetic modification of MOFs, are becoming more and more fascinating because, compared with the original MOFs, the Ln(III)-functionalized MOFs could have different excitation spectra. If the excitation spectrum of the MOF (donor) shows a certain degree of overlap with the UV-vis absorption spectrum of the analyte (acceptor), there is likely to be a competitive energy absorption process between them. The detection results may be different by different excitation wavelengths, so we can combine the Ln(III)-functionalized MOF and the original MOF to distinguish the analytes effectively. For these reasons, efforts have been made to fabricate Ln(III)-functionalized luminescence-sensing MOFs. Over the past few decades, a few Ln(III)-functionalized luminescent MOFs for sensing cations and anions have been realized. However, no reports about combining the fluorescent detection properties of the Ln(III)-functionalized MOF and the original MOF have been found.

elements.content: Recently, selective sensing of Cr­(VI) anions (Cr2O7 2–/CrO4 2–) and the Fe­(III) cation has attracted much attention. Cr­(VI) ions are potent carcinogenic and mutagenic ions that can lead to allergic reactions, hereditary genetic defects, and various types of cancers. They are also classified as serious pollutants by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Meanwhile, not only is the Fe­(III) ion recognized as an industrial pollutant but also it plays a significant role in living organisms. However, some traditional detection methods, including inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), spectrophotometry, atomic absorption spectrophotometry, and electrochemical methods, are often complicated and expensive for detecting Fe­(III) or Cr­(VI) ions. Therefore, fluorescence-based MOFs for sensing Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions are more effective and ideal because of their ease of use, low cost, and high sensitivity and selectivity. Also, a few luminescent MOFs for detecting Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions have been reported up to now. However, the luminescence intensities of these MOFs are all decreased with the addition of Fe­(III) or Cr­(VI) ions. In other words, we cannot determine whether the system under testing has Fe­(III) or Cr­(VI) ions by a change of fluorescence. For example, Liu et al. reported the complex {[Eu2L1.5(H2O)2EtOH]·DMF} n , which was used for the detection ot Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI). However, they may interfere with each other, which will limit their detection capability in practical applications. To the best of our knowledge, no reports about MOFs to differentiate Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions through fluorescence measurement have been found.
elements.clean_text: Recently, selective sensing of Cr(VI) anions (Cr2O7 2-/CrO4 2-) and the Fe(III) cation has attracted much attention. Cr(VI) ions are potent carcinogenic and mutagenic ions that can lead to allergic reactions, hereditary genetic defects, and various types of cancers. They are also classified as serious pollutants by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Meanwhile, not only is the Fe(III) ion recognized as an industrial pollutant but also it plays a significant role in living organisms. However, some traditional detection methods, including inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), spectrophotometry, atomic absorption spectrophotometry, and electrochemical methods, are often complicated and expensive for detecting Fe(III) or Cr(VI) ions. Therefore, fluorescence-based MOFs for sensing Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions are more effective and ideal because of their ease of use, low cost, and high sensitivity and selectivity. Also, a few luminescent MOFs for detecting Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions have been reported up to now. However, the luminescence intensities of these MOFs are all decreased with the addition of Fe(III) or Cr(VI) ions. In other words, we cannot determine whether the system under testing has Fe(III) or Cr(VI) ions by a change of fluorescence. For example, Liu et al. reported the complex {[Eu2L1.5(H2O)2EtOH]⋅DMF} n , which was used for the detection ot Fe(III) and Cr(VI). However, they may interfere with each other, which will limit their detection capability in practical applications. To the best of our knowledge, no reports about MOFs to differentiate Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions through fluorescence measurement have been found.

elements.content: On the basis of the above considerations, we report a 3D luminescent MOF, [Zn2(TPOM)­(NDC)2]·3.5H2O (Zn-MOF; TPOM = tetrakis­(4-pyridyloxymethylene)­methane and H2ndc = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid), and obtain the Ln-decorated MOF Eu3+@Zn-MOF. The luminescence of Zn-MOF shows high sensitivity, well antiinterference performance, and a quick response time in the presence of Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions in solution. More importantly, we can differentiate Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions by the combination of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. To the best of our knowledge, this represents the first example of MOF-based luminescent sensors that can differentiate Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions in solution through fluorescence measurement.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the above considerations, we report a 3D luminescent MOF, [Zn2(TPOM)(NDC)2]⋅3.5H2O (Zn-MOF; TPOM = tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene)methane and H2ndc = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid), and obtain the Ln-decorated MOF Eu3+@Zn-MOF. The luminescence of Zn-MOF shows high sensitivity, well antiinterference performance, and a quick response time in the presence of Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions in solution. More importantly, we can differentiate Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions by the combination of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. To the best of our knowledge, this represents the first example of MOF-based luminescent sensors that can differentiate Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions in solution through fluorescence measurement.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol), tetrakis­(4-pyridyloxymethylene)­methane (TPOM; 22.2 mg, 0.05 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2ndc; 21.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), dimethylformamide (DMF; 4 mL), and H2O (8 mL) was added to a 25 mL Telfon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated at 100 °C for 96 h, and then cooled to 25 °C within 48 h. Colorless rhombus crystals were obtained. Yield: 47.3% (based on TPOM). Elem anal. Calcd for C98H86N8O31Zn4: C, 55.18; H, 4.06; N, 5.25. Found: C, 55.36; H, 3.92; N, 5.62. FT-IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3442s, 3063m, 2954w, 2889w, 2503w, 2350w, 2143w, 1938w, 1616s, 1501s, 1385s, 1288s, 1205s, 1025s, 928m, 787s, 645w, 536m (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of [Zn2(TPOM)(NDC)2]⋅3.5H2O (Zn-MOF)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol), tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene)methane (TPOM; 22.2 mg, 0.05 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2ndc; 21.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), dimethylformamide (DMF; 4 mL), and H2O (8 mL) was added to a 25 mL Telfon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated at 100 °C for 96 h, and then cooled to 25 °C within 48 h. Colorless rhombus crystals were obtained. Yield: 47.3% (based on TPOM). Elem anal. Calcd for C98H86N8O31Zn4: C, 55.18; H, 4.06; N, 5.25. Found: C, 55.36; H, 3.92; N, 5.62. FT-IR (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3442s, 3063m, 2954w, 2889w, 2503w, 2350w, 2143w, 1938w, 1616s, 1501s, 1385s, 1288s, 1205s, 1025s, 928m, 787s, 645w, 536m (Figure S1).

elements.content:
Zn-MOF (2 mg) was ground and soaked in an aqueous solution of Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O (5 mL, 1.0 × 10–2 M), sonicated for 30 min to prepare the suspension.

Preparation for ICP-AES Analysis

A total of 2 mg of Zn-MOF was dispersed in 10 mL of Fe3+ solution (1 × 10–2 M). After immersion for 30 min, Fe3+@Zn-MOF was removed by centrifugation, and it was dispersed in 10 mL of aqueous solution. As a control, 2 mg of Zn-MOF was dispersed in 10 mL of aqueous solution. In addition, 2 mg of Eu3+@Zn-MOF was dispersed in 10 mL of aqueous solution. All of the samples were destroyed with the addition of 0.5 mL of nitric acid, and they were used for ICP-AES analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Eu3+@Zn-MOF

Zn-MOF (2 mg) was ground and soaked in an aqueous solution of Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O (5 mL, 1.0 × 10-2 M), sonicated for 30 min to prepare the suspension.

Preparation for ICP-AES Analysis

A total of 2 mg of Zn-MOF was dispersed in 10 mL of Fe3+ solution (1 × 10-2 M). After immersion for 30 min, Fe3+@Zn-MOF was removed by centrifugation, and it was dispersed in 10 mL of aqueous solution. As a control, 2 mg of Zn-MOF was dispersed in 10 mL of aqueous solution. In addition, 2 mg of Eu3+@Zn-MOF was dispersed in 10 mL of aqueous solution. All of the samples were destroyed with the addition of 0.5 mL of nitric acid, and they were used for ICP-AES analysis.

elements.content: Zn-MOF (2 mg) was ground and soaked in H2O (5 mL) and then sonicated for 30 min to obtain a suspension, which were used for luminescent experiments. The aqueous solutions of M x+ (1.0 × 10–2 M) at room temperature were prepared for luminescent experiments (M x+ = Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Co2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Fe2+, Ni2+, Mn2+, Pb2+, Ag+, Al3+, Cr3+, or Fe3+). In addition, the same concentrations (1.0 × 10–2 M) of aqueous solutions containing potassium salts of Cl–, Br–, HCO3 –, NO3 –, OAc–, CO3 2–, C2O4 2–, I–, CrO4 2–, and Cr2O7 2– were also prepared.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Sensing Experiments

Zn-MOF (2 mg) was ground and soaked in H2O (5 mL) and then sonicated for 30 min to obtain a suspension, which were used for luminescent experiments. The aqueous solutions of M x+ (1.0 × 10-2 M) at room temperature were prepared for luminescent experiments (M x+ = Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Co2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Fe2+, Ni2+, Mn2+, Pb2+, Ag+, Al3+, Cr3+, or Fe3+). In addition, the same concentrations (1.0 × 10-2 M) of aqueous solutions containing potassium salts of Cl-, Br-, HCO3 -, NO3 -, OAc-, CO3 2-, C2O4 2-, I-, CrO4 2-, and Cr2O7 2- were also prepared.

elements.content: By single-crystal diffraction analyses, Zn-MOF crystallizes in a monoclinic space group of P21/c.The asymmetric unit consists of two Zn ions, one TPOM ligand, two ndc2– anions, and three and a half solvent H2O molecules (a). Also, the Zn2+ ion adopts a four-coordinated configuration that contains two O atoms and two N atoms derived from the H2ndc molecules and TPOM ligand, respectively. The Zn2+ ions and TPOM ligands connect with each other to obtain a one-dimensional chain, which connects with H2ndc ligands to form a two-dimensional-layered structure (b), and at last the three-dimensional structure will form (c). Furthermore, from the topological perspective, Zn1 and Zn2 can be viewed as 4-connected nodes, which are connected with two carboxyl O atoms and two pyridine N atoms. Therefore, this structure can be simplified as an 2-nodal 4-connected topological net with the Schläfli symbol {4·64·82}2{42·64} and a sqc974 topology type (d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Descriptions

By single-crystal diffraction analyses, Zn-MOF crystallizes in a monoclinic space group of P21/c.The asymmetric unit consists of two Zn ions, one TPOM ligand, two ndc2- anions, and three and a half solvent H2O molecules (a). Also, the Zn2+ ion adopts a four-coordinated configuration that contains two O atoms and two N atoms derived from the H2ndc molecules and TPOM ligand, respectively. The Zn2+ ions and TPOM ligands connect with each other to obtain a one-dimensional chain, which connects with H2ndc ligands to form a two-dimensional-layered structure (b), and at last the three-dimensional structure will form (c). Furthermore, from the topological perspective, Zn1 and Zn2 can be viewed as 4-connected nodes, which are connected with two carboxyl O atoms and two pyridine N atoms. Therefore, this structure can be simplified as an 2-nodal 4-connected topological net with the Schläfli symbol {4⋅64⋅82}2{42⋅64} and a sqc974 topology type (d).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Zn2+ in Zn-MOF. All H atoms and lattice H2O molecules are omitted for clarity. (b) Two-dimensional-layered structure of Zn-MOF. (c) View of the three-dimensional structure of Zn-MOF. (d) Topology graph of Zn-MOF.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of Zn2+ in Zn-MOF. All H atoms and lattice H2O molecules are omitted for clarity. (b) Two-dimensional-layered structure of Zn-MOF. (c) View of the three-dimensional structure of Zn-MOF. (d) Topology graph of Zn-MOF.

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) of the as-synthesized Zn-MOF confirmed the phase purity by matching the simulated pattern (Figure S2). In order to inspect the stability of the compound, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out under a nitrogen flow, and the temperature was varied from 25 to 800 °C. The weight loss above 370 °C was attributed to decomposition of the framework. The corresponding TGA curve of the compound is illustrated in Figure S3. Afterward, Zn-MOF was soaked in an aqueous solution of Eu­(NO3)3 to obtain the Eu-decorated MOF, Eu3+@Zn-MOF. The property characterization of Eu3+@Zn-MOF was investigated. The crystalline integrity of Zn-MOF remained unchanged after the incorporation of a Eu3+ ion, which can been confirmed by XRD (Figure S2). In order to explore the stability of the MOFs, the samples were treated with water. After immersion in an aqueous solution for 24 h, the XRD patterns of the MOFs show unchanged structures, which demonstrate their excellent stability (Figure S2). To obtain the number of Eu3+ ions entering into Zn-MOF, ICP-AES analysis on Eu3+@Zn-MOF has been performed. As shown in Table S3, the ratio of Zn2+ and Eu3+ is about 1:1 (1:0.81), which suggests that one noncoordinating carboxyl O atom may be interacting with one Eu3+ ion. To certify the coordination between the noncoordinating carboxyl O atom on Zn-MOF and the Eu3+ ions, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis on Eu3+@Zn-MOF was performed. As shown in Figure S4, the Eu 3d peak position of Eu3+@Zn-MOF at 1134.5 e is lower than that of Eu­(NO3)3 (1136.4 eV), and the Eu 4d peak position at 136.8 eV is lower than that of Eu­(NO3)3 (137.7 eV), which further confirms the successful coordination of the carboxyl O atom to the Eu3+ ion.
elements.clean_text:
Property Characterization

The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) of the as-synthesized Zn-MOF confirmed the phase purity by matching the simulated pattern (Figure S2). In order to inspect the stability of the compound, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out under a nitrogen flow, and the temperature was varied from 25 to 800 °C. The weight loss above 370 °C was attributed to decomposition of the framework. The corresponding TGA curve of the compound is illustrated in Figure S3. Afterward, Zn-MOF was soaked in an aqueous solution of Eu(NO3)3 to obtain the Eu-decorated MOF, Eu3+@Zn-MOF. The property characterization of Eu3+@Zn-MOF was investigated. The crystalline integrity of Zn-MOF remained unchanged after the incorporation of a Eu3+ ion, which can been confirmed by XRD (Figure S2). In order to explore the stability of the MOFs, the samples were treated with water. After immersion in an aqueous solution for 24 h, the XRD patterns of the MOFs show unchanged structures, which demonstrate their excellent stability (Figure S2). To obtain the number of Eu3+ ions entering into Zn-MOF, ICP-AES analysis on Eu3+@Zn-MOF has been performed. As shown in Table S3, the ratio of Zn2+ and Eu3+ is about 1:1 (1:0.81), which suggests that one noncoordinating carboxyl O atom may be interacting with one Eu3+ ion. To certify the coordination between the noncoordinating carboxyl O atom on Zn-MOF and the Eu3+ ions, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis on Eu3+@Zn-MOF was performed. As shown in Figure S4, the Eu 3d peak position of Eu3+@Zn-MOF at 1134.5 e is lower than that of Eu(NO3)3 (1136.4 eV), and the Eu 4d peak position at 136.8 eV is lower than that of Eu(NO3)3 (137.7 eV), which further confirms the successful coordination of the carboxyl O atom to the Eu3+ ion.

elements.content: Zn-MOF was constructed by the Zn2+ ion and aromatic organic ligands, which made it a promising candidate as a luminescent material; therefore, we researched the fluorescence property of Zn-MOF for the first time. As shown in Figure S5, the fluorescence emission of Zn-MOF dispersed in aqueous solution is very strong, which made us explore its application as a fluorescent sensor. Also, the luminescent spectra of Eu3+@Zn-MOF were also recorded. As expected, the emission spectrum of Eu3+@Zn-MOF exhibited characteristic emissions of Eu3+ at 592, 616, and 698 nm, which originated from 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1, 2, 4) transitions of Eu3+, and an obvious red light can be observed under UV-light irradiation of 365 nm (Figure S6).
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Properties

Zn-MOF was constructed by the Zn2+ ion and aromatic organic ligands, which made it a promising candidate as a luminescent material; therefore, we researched the fluorescence property of Zn-MOF for the first time. As shown in Figure S5, the fluorescence emission of Zn-MOF dispersed in aqueous solution is very strong, which made us explore its application as a fluorescent sensor. Also, the luminescent spectra of Eu3+@Zn-MOF were also recorded. As expected, the emission spectrum of Eu3+@Zn-MOF exhibited characteristic emissions of Eu3+ at 592, 616, and 698 nm, which originated from 5D0 → 7F J  (J = 1, 2, 4) transitions of Eu3+, and an obvious red light can be observed under UV-light irradiation of 365 nm (Figure S6).

elements.content: To explore the potential sensing ability of Zn-MOF for various metal ions, we performed a series of luminescence-based experiments by the gradual addition of different metal ions to an aqueous suspension of Zn-MOF. The luminescence intensity of Zn-MOF rapidly decreased with the addition of Fe3+ ions ( and S7a). As shown in Figure S8, other metal ions have a negligible effect on the luminescence intensity of Zn-MOF except Cr3+ and Pb2+. Although the luminescence intensity is decreased to some degree with the addition of Cr3+ and Pb2+, their quenching abilities are much weaker than that of Fe3+ ion. This indicates that Zn-MOF can detect Fe3+ ions selectively among various metal ions. As we all known, the antiinterference ability is very important for sensors, so a series of antijamming experiments were performed. As shown in , initially, the fluorescence intensity of Zn-MOF shows negligible change with the addition of other metal ions. However, the luminescence intensity rapidly decreased with the addition of Fe3+ to the mixed solution of Zn-MOF and other metal ions. The decrease of the fluorescence intensity indicates that it can detect Fe3+ ion even in the presence of other metal ions. Satisfyingly, the response time is quite short, and it can control in 30 s. Quantitatively, the quenching efficiency was calculated by the Stern–Volmer equation: I 0/I = 1 + K SV[Q], where I 0 represents the initial luminescence intensity, I is the luminescence intensity after the addition of a Fe­(III) ion, [Q] is the concentration of the Fe­(III) ion, and K SV represents the quenching constant. As shown in Figure S9a, the Stern–Volmer plot is almost linear at low concentration, and the quenching constant, K SV, is 1.9 × 104 M–1 for Zn-MOF. However, the Stern–Volmer plot deviates from the straight line at higher concentrations (Figure S9b), and this phenomenon may be attributed to self-absorption or an energy-transfer process. In addition, the detection limit (LOD) of Fe3+ ions was calculated by the ratio of 3δ/slope, and it can as low as 2 μM. It exhibits a better performance, and the specific comparison of some MOF fluorescent sensors for detecting Fe3+ ion is listed (Table S6).
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Ions

To explore the potential sensing ability of Zn-MOF for various metal ions, we performed a series of luminescence-based experiments by the gradual addition of different metal ions to an aqueous suspension of Zn-MOF. The luminescence intensity of Zn-MOF rapidly decreased with the addition of Fe3+ ions ( and S7a). As shown in Figure S8, other metal ions have a negligible effect on the luminescence intensity of Zn-MOF except Cr3+ and Pb2+. Although the luminescence intensity is decreased to some degree with the addition of Cr3+ and Pb2+, their quenching abilities are much weaker than that of Fe3+ ion. This indicates that Zn-MOF can detect Fe3+ ions selectively among various metal ions. As we all known, the antiinterference ability is very important for sensors, so a series of antijamming experiments were performed. As shown in , initially, the fluorescence intensity of Zn-MOF shows negligible change with the addition of other metal ions. However, the luminescence intensity rapidly decreased with the addition of Fe3+ to the mixed solution of Zn-MOF and other metal ions. The decrease of the fluorescence intensity indicates that it can detect Fe3+ ion even in the presence of other metal ions. Satisfyingly, the response time is quite short, and it can control in 30 s. Quantitatively, the quenching efficiency was calculated by the Stern-Volmer equation: I 0/I = 1 + K SV[Q], where I 0 represents the initial luminescence intensity, I is the luminescence intensity after the addition of a Fe(III) ion, [Q] is the concentration of the Fe(III) ion, and K SV represents the quenching constant. As shown in Figure S9a, the Stern-Volmer plot is almost linear at low concentration, and the quenching constant, K SV, is 1.9 × 104 M-1 for Zn-MOF. However, the Stern-Volmer plot deviates from the straight line at higher concentrations (Figure S9b), and this phenomenon may be attributed to self-absorption or an energy-transfer process. In addition, the detection limit (LOD) of Fe3+ ions was calculated by the ratio of 3δ/slope, and it can as low as 2 μM. It exhibits a better performance, and the specific comparison of some MOF fluorescent sensors for detecting Fe3+ ion is listed (Table S6).

elements.content: Fluorescence intensity of Zn-MOF at 371 nm at different Fe3+ concentrations (excited at 296 nm).
elements.clean_text: 2  Fluorescence intensity of Zn-MOF at 371 nm at different Fe3+ concentrations (excited at 296 nm).

elements.content: Fluorescence responses of Zn-MOF (at 371 nm) to different ions (purple bars, emission intensities of Zn-MOF with different ions (400 μM); blue bars, changes in the emission with the subsequent addition of Fe3+ ion (400 μM) to the above solution).
elements.clean_text: 3  Fluorescence responses of Zn-MOF (at 371 nm) to different ions (purple bars, emission intensities of Zn-MOF with different ions (400 μM); blue bars, changes in the emission with the subsequent addition of Fe3+ ion (400 μM) to the above solution).

elements.content: Potassium salts of halide ions, NO3 –, OAc–, HCO3 –, C2O4 2–, CO3 2–, CrO4 2–, and Cr2O7 2–, were prepared, and we investigated their effects on the fluorescence intensity of Zn-MOF. Similar to metal ions, theie fluorescence intensities are also dependent on the different anions. The fluorescence intensity of Zn-MOF gradually decreases with the addition of Cr­(VI) ions (a,b and S7b,c); however, the other anions show a negligible influence (), which indicates that Zn-MOF can detect Cr­(VI) ions selectively. To investigate the ability of Zn-MOF for detecting Cr­(VI) in the presence of other anions, a series of competition experiments were performed. With the addition of Cr­(VI) ions into the mixed solution of Zn-MOF and other anions, the corresponding luminescence spectra were recorded. As shown in c,d, a remarkable fluorescence decline can be observed after the addition of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– to the mixed solution; this indicates that Zn-MOF has a good selectivity and antiinterference ability for detecting Cr­(VI) ions. At low concentrations, good linearity plots of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– were obtained (Figure S9c,e), with correlation coefficients of 0.994 and 0.990. Also, the corresponding quenching constants have been calculated, which are 9.21 × 103 M–1 for Cr2O7 2– and 7.81 × 103 M –1 for CrO4 2–, respectively. Similar to that in detecting the Fe3+ ion, the Stern–Volmer plots become nonlinear at higher concentrations (Figure S9d,f). In addition, the LODs based on Zn-MOF for Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– ions are also calculated and are 2.35 and 2.50 μM, respectively. They are lower than the maximum contamination standard of Cr­(VI) in wastewater of 10 μM, defined by an integrated wastewater discharge standard. Also, a specific comparison of some MOF fluorescent sensors for detecting Cr­(VI) ion is given (Table S7).
elements.clean_text: Potassium salts of halide ions, NO3 -, OAc-, HCO3 -, C2O4 2-, CO3 2-, CrO4 2-, and Cr2O7 2-, were prepared, and we investigated their effects on the fluorescence intensity of Zn-MOF. Similar to metal ions, theie fluorescence intensities are also dependent on the different anions. The fluorescence intensity of Zn-MOF gradually decreases with the addition of Cr(VI) ions (a,b and S7b,c); however, the other anions show a negligible influence (), which indicates that Zn-MOF can detect Cr(VI) ions selectively. To investigate the ability of Zn-MOF for detecting Cr(VI) in the presence of other anions, a series of competition experiments were performed. With the addition of Cr(VI) ions into the mixed solution of Zn-MOF and other anions, the corresponding luminescence spectra were recorded. As shown in c,d, a remarkable fluorescence decline can be observed after the addition of Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- to the mixed solution; this indicates that Zn-MOF has a good selectivity and antiinterference ability for detecting Cr(VI) ions. At low concentrations, good linearity plots of Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- were obtained (Figure S9c,e), with correlation coefficients of 0.994 and 0.990. Also, the corresponding quenching constants have been calculated, which are 9.21 × 103 M-1 for Cr2O7 2- and 7.81 × 103 M -1 for CrO4 2-, respectively. Similar to that in detecting the Fe3+ ion, the Stern-Volmer plots become nonlinear at higher concentrations (Figure S9d,f). In addition, the LODs based on Zn-MOF for Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- ions are also calculated and are 2.35 and 2.50 μM, respectively. They are lower than the maximum contamination standard of Cr(VI) in wastewater of 10 μM, defined by an integrated wastewater discharge standard. Also, a specific comparison of some MOF fluorescent sensors for detecting Cr(VI) ion is given (Table S7).

elements.content: It is worth noting that we can not determine the system contains Fe­(III) or Cr­(VI) by decreasing the Zn-MOF luminescence intensity. In order to improve the selectivity of Zn-MOF, we obtained Eu3+@Zn-MOF. Relevant titration experiments were performed with the addition of Fe­(III) or Cr­(VI) ions to a suspension of Eu3+@Zn-MOF. Strikingly, although the luminescence intensity of Eu3+@Zn-MOF decreases with the addition of Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions, the quenching efficiency for the Cr­(VI) ion is significantly better than that of the Fe­(III) ion ( and S10). Compared with Zn-MOF, the effect of the Fe­(III) ion on the luminescence intensity of Eu3+@Zn-MOF is significantly small (a,b). However, the effects of the Cr­(VI) ion for both the Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF luminescence intensities are roughly same (c,d). To better understand and compare K sv and LOD with that of Zn-MOF, we get the Stern–Volmer plots of Eu3+@Zn-MOF for Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) (Figure S11), and the corresponding comparison is shown in Table S4. For Fe­(III), K SV[Zn-MOF]/K SV[Eu3+@Zn-MOF] is 11.9, and for Cr­(VI) ions, K SV[Zn-MOF]/K SV[Eu3+@Zn-MOF] is 1.3 for Cr2O7 2– and 2.4 for CrO4 2–, respectively. In addition, for the Fe­(III) ion, LOD­[Eu3+@Zn-MOF]/LOD­[Zn-MOF] is 3.2, and for Cr­(VI) ions, LOD­[Eu3+@Zn-MOF]/LOD­[Zn-MOF] is 1.2 for Cr2O7 2– and 1.8 for CrO4 2–, respectively. Also, the analysis results can be further certified in the above conclusions. As a result, although Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions can make the luminescence intensity of Zn-MOF decrease, the changes of the luminescence intensity of Eu3+@Zn-MOF are different, and we can combine the changes of the luminescence intensities of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF to differentiate Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions.
elements.clean_text:
Differentiation of Fe(III) and Cr(VI) Ions

It is worth noting that we can not determine the system contains Fe(III) or Cr(VI) by decreasing the Zn-MOF luminescence intensity. In order to improve the selectivity of Zn-MOF, we obtained Eu3+@Zn-MOF. Relevant titration experiments were performed with the addition of Fe(III) or Cr(VI) ions to a suspension of Eu3+@Zn-MOF. Strikingly, although the luminescence intensity of Eu3+@Zn-MOF decreases with the addition of Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions, the quenching efficiency for the Cr(VI) ion is significantly better than that of the Fe(III) ion ( and S10). Compared with Zn-MOF, the effect of the Fe(III) ion on the luminescence intensity of Eu3+@Zn-MOF is significantly small (a,b). However, the effects of the Cr(VI) ion for both the Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF luminescence intensities are roughly same (c,d). To better understand and compare K sv and LOD with that of Zn-MOF, we get the Stern-Volmer plots of Eu3+@Zn-MOF for Fe(III) and Cr(VI) (Figure S11), and the corresponding comparison is shown in Table S4. For Fe(III), K SV[Zn-MOF]/K SV[Eu3+@Zn-MOF] is 11.9, and for Cr(VI) ions, K SV[Zn-MOF]/K SV[Eu3+@Zn-MOF] is 1.3 for Cr2O7 2- and 2.4 for CrO4 2-, respectively. In addition, for the Fe(III) ion, LOD[Eu3+@Zn-MOF]/LOD[Zn-MOF] is 3.2, and for Cr(VI) ions, LOD[Eu3+@Zn-MOF]/LOD[Zn-MOF] is 1.2 for Cr2O7 2- and 1.8 for CrO4 2-, respectively. Also, the analysis results can be further certified in the above conclusions. As a result, although Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions can make the luminescence intensity of Zn-MOF decrease, the changes of the luminescence intensity of Eu3+@Zn-MOF are different, and we can combine the changes of the luminescence intensities of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF to differentiate Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions.

elements.clean_text: 7  Fluorescence intensities of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF at 371 and 617 nm at different Fe3+ (a) and Cr2O7 2- (c) concentrations and the corresponding quenching efficiencies of Fe3+ (b) and Cr2O7 2- (d).

elements.content: To make visual detection and differentiation come true, photographs of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF with various analytes under UV-light irradiation of 365 nm were provided. For Zn-MOF, there were no significant color variations with the addition of other analytes except Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions, which become dark (Figure S12). This phenomenon indicates that Zn-MOF could perform visual detection. Also, the fluorescent colors of Eu3+@Zn-MOF become dark with the addition of Cr­(VI) ions; however, there were no significant color variations with the addition of a Fe3+ ion (Figure S13), which indicates that Eu3+@Zn-MOF can make the visual differentiation come ture. In order to make the detection and differentiation more simple, the test paper has been attempted for the detection of Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions. The test paper can be obtained by immersing the filter paper in H2O of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF and allowing it to air-dry. Also, the test paper maintains the excellent luminescence properties of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. With the dropping of Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions into an aqueous solution, the fluorescent colors of the test paper of Zn-MOF have a significant change under irradiation of a UV lamp of 365 nm, and the overall trend is becoming dark (). However, the fluorescent colors of the test paper of Eu3+@Zn-MOF are significantly different with the addition of Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions (), which can be used to distinguish the Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions. In general, we can differentiate the Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions effectively by combining Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. More importantly, visual detection and the test paper make the detection and differentiation more convenient.
elements.clean_text: To make visual detection and differentiation come true, photographs of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF with various analytes under UV-light irradiation of 365 nm were provided. For Zn-MOF, there were no significant color variations with the addition of other analytes except Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions, which become dark (Figure S12). This phenomenon indicates that Zn-MOF could perform visual detection. Also, the fluorescent colors of Eu3+@Zn-MOF become dark with the addition of Cr(VI) ions; however, there were no significant color variations with the addition of a Fe3+ ion (Figure S13), which indicates that Eu3+@Zn-MOF can make the visual differentiation come ture. In order to make the detection and differentiation more simple, the test paper has been attempted for the detection of Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions. The test paper can be obtained by immersing the filter paper in H2O of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF and allowing it to air-dry. Also, the test paper maintains the excellent luminescence properties of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. With the dropping of Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions into an aqueous solution, the fluorescent colors of the test paper of Zn-MOF have a significant change under irradiation of a UV lamp of 365 nm, and the overall trend is becoming dark (). However, the fluorescent colors of the test paper of Eu3+@Zn-MOF are significantly different with the addition of Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions (), which can be used to distinguish the Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions. In general, we can differentiate the Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions effectively by combining Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. More importantly, visual detection and the test paper make the detection and differentiation more convenient.

elements.content: Here, the possible sensing mechanism for the luminescence quenching by Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions was investigated. First, the XRD pattern spectra of Zn-MOF after detecting Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions are consistent with the original sample, suggesting that the basic frameworks remain unchanged (Figure S14). Second, the response time is quite short, which implies that cation exchange should be ruled out. Also, to validate the viewpoint, ICP analysis was performed; as shown in Table S5, there is no change in the number of Zn2+ ions before and after the detection of Fe3+ ion. Third, the competitive energy absorption was supposed to a probable reason for the luminescence quenching. Generally speaking, there is likely to be a competitive energy absorption between the MOF and analyte if the excitation spectrum of the MOF shows a certain extent of overlap with the UV–vis absorption spectrum of the analyte. As shown in Figure S15, the UV–vis absorption spectra of a Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) aqueous solution show obvious overlap with the excitation spectrum of Zn-MOF, which indicates that Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions can strongly absorb the energy of the excitation light and ultimately result in luminescence quenching. However, compared with Zn-MOF, the excitation spectrum of Eu3+@Zn-MOF has changed. As shown in Figure S16, there is extensive spectral overlap between the UV–vis absorption spectrum of the Cr­(VI) ion and the excitation spectrum of Eu3+@Zn-MOF, but the spectral overlap between the Fe­(III) ion and Eu3+@Zn-MOF is obviously reduced, which is consistent with the experimental result. In addition, Zn-MOF is selected as a parent coordination compound to encapsulate Eu3+ cations to obtain Eu3+@Zn-MOF. Therefore, compared with Zn-MOF, there is an obvious decline for the adsorption capacity of Eu3+@Zn-MOF for Fe3+ (Figure S17), which also has a certain effect for detection of the Fe3+ ion. In order to further certify the above statement, the detection experiment of Zn-MOF upon the incremental addition of Fe3+, Cr2O7 2–, and CrO4 2– at excitation as supplied in the case of Eu3+@Zn-MOF was done. As shown in Figures S18 and S19, the quenching efficiency of Fe3+ become weaker at an excitation of 349 nm, which is consistent with the discussion of the mechanism. In addition, the final quenching effect of Fe3+ is consistent with an excitation of 296 nm, which also demonstrates that the adsorption capacity of Zn-MOF for Fe3+ ion is also important for detection. To discuss the quenching mechanism further, the lifetime decay of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF in the presence and absence of analytes was measured. However, the fluorescence intensity of Zn-MOF is very weak when the concentration of Fe­(III) ions is same as that of Cr­(VI) ions, which leads to the inability to perform the lifetime test. As a result, we only provide the lifetime decay of Zn-MOF in the presence and absence of Cr­(VI). As shown in Figure S20, the lifetimes were shortened from 8.722 to 8.360 ns and from 8.722 to 8.420 ns after Zn-MOF was treated with Cr­(VI) ions, and the upward Stern–Volmer curve at higher Cr­(VI) ion concentrations demonstrated that both static and dynamic mechanisms operate at higher concentration. However, the lifetime of Eu3+@Zn-MOF remained in the presence and absence of Fe­(III) or Cr­(VI) ions (Figure S21), and the Stern–Volmer plots are linear at the full concentration region, which suggests that there is a static quenching mechanism.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion of the Mechanism

Here, the possible sensing mechanism for the luminescence quenching by Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions was investigated. First, the XRD pattern spectra of Zn-MOF after detecting Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions are consistent with the original sample, suggesting that the basic frameworks remain unchanged (Figure S14). Second, the response time is quite short, which implies that cation exchange should be ruled out. Also, to validate the viewpoint, ICP analysis was performed; as shown in Table S5, there is no change in the number of Zn2+ ions before and after the detection of Fe3+ ion. Third, the competitive energy absorption was supposed to a probable reason for the luminescence quenching. Generally speaking, there is likely to be a competitive energy absorption between the MOF and analyte if the excitation spectrum of the MOF shows a certain extent of overlap with the UV-vis absorption spectrum of the analyte. As shown in Figure S15, the UV-vis absorption spectra of a Fe(III) and Cr(VI) aqueous solution show obvious overlap with the excitation spectrum of Zn-MOF, which indicates that Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions can strongly absorb the energy of the excitation light and ultimately result in luminescence quenching. However, compared with Zn-MOF, the excitation spectrum of Eu3+@Zn-MOF has changed. As shown in Figure S16, there is extensive spectral overlap between the UV-vis absorption spectrum of the Cr(VI) ion and the excitation spectrum of Eu3+@Zn-MOF, but the spectral overlap between the Fe(III) ion and Eu3+@Zn-MOF is obviously reduced, which is consistent with the experimental result. In addition, Zn-MOF is selected as a parent coordination compound to encapsulate Eu3+ cations to obtain Eu3+@Zn-MOF. Therefore, compared with Zn-MOF, there is an obvious decline for the adsorption capacity of Eu3+@Zn-MOF for Fe3+ (Figure S17), which also has a certain effect for detection of the Fe3+ ion. In order to further certify the above statement, the detection experiment of Zn-MOF upon the incremental addition of Fe3+, Cr2O7 2-, and CrO4 2- at excitation as supplied in the case of Eu3+@Zn-MOF was done. As shown in Figures S18 and S19, the quenching efficiency of Fe3+ become weaker at an excitation of 349 nm, which is consistent with the discussion of the mechanism. In addition, the final quenching effect of Fe3+ is consistent with an excitation of 296 nm, which also demonstrates that the adsorption capacity of Zn-MOF for Fe3+ ion is also important for detection. To discuss the quenching mechanism further, the lifetime decay of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF in the presence and absence of analytes was measured. However, the fluorescence intensity of Zn-MOF is very weak when the concentration of Fe(III) ions is same as that of Cr(VI) ions, which leads to the inability to perform the lifetime test. As a result, we only provide the lifetime decay of Zn-MOF in the presence and absence of Cr(VI). As shown in Figure S20, the lifetimes were shortened from 8.722 to 8.360 ns and from 8.722 to 8.420 ns after Zn-MOF was treated with Cr(VI) ions, and the upward Stern-Volmer curve at higher Cr(VI) ion concentrations demonstrated that both static and dynamic mechanisms operate at higher concentration. However, the lifetime of Eu3+@Zn-MOF remained in the presence and absence of Fe(III) or Cr(VI) ions (Figure S21), and the Stern-Volmer  plots are linear at the full concentration region, which suggests that there is a static quenching mechanism.

elements.content: In summary, a Zn­(II)-based metal–organic framework (Zn-MOF) was constructed and exhibited high selectivity and sensitivity and quick response time toward Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions. Also, the quenching effect of Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions on Zn-MOF luminescence was not influenced by the presence of other ions. In addition, Eu3+@Zn-MOF was obtained. Also, we can differentiate Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions by the combination of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. More importantly, this represents the first example of MOF-based luminescent sensors that can differentiate Fe­(III) with Cr­(VI) ions through the fluorescence mechanism. This work demonstrates the potential application of Zn-MOF for the selective detection and differentiation Fe­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions, and it also provides a new facile route to designing functional MOFs as fluorescent sensors. However, how to improve the utilization efficiency of MOFs is still an urgent question.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a Zn(II)-based metal-organic framework (Zn-MOF) was constructed and exhibited high selectivity and sensitivity and quick response time toward Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions. Also, the quenching effect of Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions on Zn-MOF luminescence was not influenced by the presence of other ions. In addition, Eu3+@Zn-MOF was obtained. Also, we can differentiate Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions by the combination of Zn-MOF and Eu3+@Zn-MOF. More importantly, this represents the first example of MOF-based luminescent sensors that can differentiate Fe(III) with Cr(VI) ions through the fluorescence mechanism. This work demonstrates the potential application of Zn-MOF for the selective detection and differentiation Fe(III) and Cr(VI) ions, and it also provides a new facile route to designing functional MOFs as fluorescent sensors. However, how to improve the utilization efficiency of MOFs is still an urgent question.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol), tetrakis­(4-pyridyloxymethylene)­methane (TPOM; 22.2 mg, 0.05 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2ndc; 21.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), dimethylformamide (DMF; 4 mL), and H2O (8 mL) was added to a 25 mL Telfon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated at 100 °C for 96 h, and then cooled to 25 °C within 48 h. Colorless rhombus crystals were obtained. Yield: 47.3% (based on TPOM). Elem anal. Calcd for C98H86N8O31Zn4: C, 55.18; H, 4.06; N, 5.25. Found: C, 55.36; H, 3.92; N, 5.62. FT-IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3442s, 3063m, 2954w, 2889w, 2503w, 2350w, 2143w, 1938w, 1616s, 1501s, 1385s, 1288s, 1205s, 1025s, 928m, 787s, 645w, 536m (Figure S1).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of [Zn2(TPOM)(NDC)2]⋅3.5H2O (Zn-MOF)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol), tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene)methane (TPOM; 22.2 mg, 0.05 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2ndc; 21.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), dimethylformamide (DMF; 4 mL), and H2O (8 mL) was added to a 25 mL Telfon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated at 100 °C for 96 h, and then cooled to 25 °C within 48 h. Colorless rhombus crystals were obtained. Yield: 47.3% (based on TPOM). Elem anal. Calcd for C98H86N8O31Zn4: C, 55.18; H, 4.06; N, 5.25. Found: C, 55.36; H, 3.92; N, 5.62. FT-IR (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3442s, 3063m, 2954w, 2889w, 2503w, 2350w, 2143w, 1938w, 1616s, 1501s, 1385s, 1288s, 1205s, 1025s, 928m, 787s, 645w, 536m (Figure S1).

metadata.title:
